title: A 12-Week, Multicenter, Open Label Study To Evaluate The Effectiveness And Safety Of Donepezil Hydrochloride (E2020) In Subjects With Mild To Severe Alzheimer's Disease Residing In An Assisted Living Facility
description_brief: This is a study to determine the effectiveness and safety of donepezil hydrochloride (E2020) used to treat residents of assisted living facilities diagnosed with mild, moderate, or severe stage Alzheimer's disease.

groups.title: Donepezil Hydrochloride (HCl)
groups.description: Donepezil HCl 5 milligrams (mg) per day (one 5 mg tablet) was administered for the first 6 weeks (42 days), and then the dose was increased to 10 mg/day (two 5 mg tablets). If 10 mg of donepezil was not tolerated, the dosage was reduced temporarily to 5 mg. The participant was re-challenged with 10 mg of study drug within 5 to 7 days. If the participant still could not tolerate the higher dose after re-challenge, they continued in the study on 5 mg per day of study drug.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Safety population included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication.

groups.title: Donepezil Hydrochloride (HCl)
groups.description: Donepezil HCl 5 milligram (mg) per day (one 5 mg tablet) was administered for the first 6 weeks (42 days), and then the dose was increased to 10 mg/day (two 5 mg tablets). If 10 mg of donepezil was not tolerated, the dosage was reduced temporarily to 5 mg. The participant was re-challenged with 10 mg of study drug within 5 to 7 days. If the participant still could not tolerate the higher dose after re-challenge, they continued in the study on 5 mg per day of study drug.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) Total Scores by Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: The MMSE was a brief test that assessed the cognitive status of the participant. The 30-point test included items that evaluate orientation to time and place, immediate and delayed recall, attention, language, and construction. The total number of correct responses was obtained. The scores ranged from 0 to 30, with higher scores representing better performance. Summaries and analyses in the Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population were carried out using observed cases at each visit. A Study Endpoint evaluation was performed using the last observation carried forward (LOCF) from the open label treatment phase for each participant. The outcome of the study was based on analyses of the primary efficacy variable at Study Endpoint, which was defined as end of study assessment, using the ITT population with LOCF.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: ITT population with LOCF included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication, and had baseline and at least one post-baseline assessment of at least one efficacy variable.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline (Visit 2), Week 6 (Visit 3), Week 12 (Visit 4) or Early Termination (ET) Visit, Week 12 LOCF (Study Endpoint)

groups.title: Donepezil Hydrochloride (HCl)
groups.description: Donepezil HCl 5 milligram (mg) per day (one 5 mg tablet) was administered for the first 6 weeks (42 days), and then the dose was increased to 10 mg/day (two 5 mg tablets). If 10 mg of donepezil was not tolerated, the dosage was reduced temporarily to 5 mg. The participant was re-challenged with 10 mg of study drug within 5 to 7 days. If the participant still could not tolerate the higher dose after re-challenge, they continued in the study on 5 mg per day of study drug.

outcomeMeasures.title: Caregiver Activity Survey (CAS) Total Time by Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: The CAS was a validated tool that measured the time caregivers spent aiding Alzheimer's participants with their day-to-day activities. The CAS recorded time spent on six activities of daily living, communicating with the person, using transportation, dressing, eating, looking after one's appearance, and supervising the person. Caregivers were asked to report the amount of time spent on each activity during a 'typical' caregiving day. Total time for the CAS was calculated as the sum of the sub-item times.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: ITT population included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication, and had baseline and at least one post-baseline assessment of at least one efficacy variable. Study endpoint evaluation at week 12 included ITT population with LOCF.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline (Visit 2), Week 6 (Visit 3), Week 12 (Visit 4) or ET Visit, Week 12 LOCF (Study Endpoint)

classes.title: Change from Baseline at Week 12 LOCF

outcomeMeasures.title: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI-8) Total Score by Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: The NPI-8 was an 8-item scale that assessed eight behavioral domains: delusions, hallucinations, agitation, depression, anxiety, apathy, irritability, and aberrant motor behavior. The frequency (0 to 4) and severity (0 to 3) of each domain were assessed; the sub-score for each domain was calculated as the product of the frequency and severity rating. The total score for the NPI was calculated as the sum of the domain sub-score, range from 0 to 96, with higher scores indicating greater behavior disturbances.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: ITT population included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication, and had baseline and at least one post-baseline assessment of at least one efficacy variable. Study endpoint evaluation at week 12 included ITT population with LOCF.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer Disease-related Quality of Life (ADRQL) Total Score by Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: The ADRQL was an observer-rated quality of life instrument that measured the following domains: social interaction, awareness of self, feelings and mood, enjoyment of activities, and response to surroundings. The ADRQL was a 47-item questionnaire with five domains: relating to and being around other people (ADRQL-A; 12 items), a person's special identity and important relationships (ADRQL-B; 8 items), different types of behavior (ADRQL-C; 15 items), usual activities (ADRQL-D; 5 items), and behavior in a person's living environment (ADRQL-E; 7 items). Domain sub-scores were summed to yield a total raw score, which was divided by the total possible score and multiplied by 100 to produce the final score. Each subscale score could be calculated in the similar approach. Total score ranges from 0-100 where higher scores reflected a better quality of life.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: ITT population included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication, and had baseline and at least one post-baseline assessment of at least one efficacy variable. Study endpoint evaluation at week 12 included ITT population with LOCF.

classes.title: Change from Baseline at Week 12 LOCF

outcomeMeasures.title: Disability Assessment in Dementia (DAD) Total Score by Visit
outcomeMeasures.description: The DAD was a 10 domain 40-item scale that measured a participant's ability to initiate, plan, organize, and perform both basic and instrumental activities of daily living. These domains were: hygiene (7 items), dressing (5 items), continence (2 items), eating (3 items), meal preparation (3 items), telephoning (4 items), going on an outing (5 items), finance (4 items), medication (2 items), and leisure (5 items). The three responses to the DAD items were "No, Yes, and N/A". A "No" answer scored 0 and a "Yes" answer scored 1. The scoring range was 0-40, with a higher score indicating less disability (better quality of life). If N/A was selected then it was treated as missing. When there were items with missing values, the domain sub-scores and the total score were imputed. Domain sub-scores were summed to yield a total raw score. This was divided by the total possible score and multiplied by 100 to produce the final score. Each subscale score can be calculated in the similar approach.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: ITT population included all enrolled participants who took at least one dose of study medication, and had baseline and at least one post-baseline assessment of at least one efficacy variable. Study endpoint evaluation at week 12 included ITT population with LOCF.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline (Visit 2), Week 6 (Visit 3), Week 12 (Visit 4) or ET Visit, Week 12 LOCF (Study Endpoint)

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: All adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) were collected from Screening Visit 1 (-21 to -14 days) until Week 12 Visit 4 (Day 84) or early termination. AEs/SAEs were collected for approximately 4 months.
adverseEventsModule.description: Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) and treatment-emergent serious adverse events were reported. TEAEs were defined as events that occurred after the first dose of study drug or a pre-existing condition that worsened after starting study drug. The safety population was analyzed and included enrolled participants who received at least one dose of study drug.

eventGroups.title: Donepezil Hydrochloride (HCl)
eventGroups.description: Donepezil HCl 5 mg per day (one 5 mg tablet) was administered for the first 6 weeks (42 days), and then the dose was increased to 10 mg/day (two 5 mg tablets). If 10 mg of donepezil was not tolerated, the dosage was reduced temporarily to 5 mg. The participant was re-challenged with 10 mg of study drug within 5 to 7 days. If the participant still could not tolerate the higher dose after re-challenge, they continued in the study on 5 mg per day of study drug.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests donepezil hydrochloride (E2020), which is a centrally acting, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases synaptic acetylcholine and is used to improve cognition and global function in Alzheimer's disease. Donepezil is a small‑molecule symptomatic treatment (it does not alter underlying amyloid/tau pathology) and is indicated for mild, moderate and severe Alzheimer’s dementia. citeturn1search10turn1search8turn1search5

Act: Key extracted details — Drug name: Donepezil hydrochloride (E2020). Intervention type: small‑molecule acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (symptomatic cholinergic enhancer). Trial population: residents of assisted‑living facilities with mild, moderate or severe Alzheimer’s disease (trial listing). Intended effect in the protocol: effectiveness and safety in treating AD symptoms (cognitive/global function), not described as a disease‑modifying therapy. citeturn0search6turn0search8turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — by the definitions provided, ‘‘Disease‑targeted biologic’’ requires a biologic (monoclonal antibody, vaccine) targeting pathology (not met); ‘‘Disease‑targeted small molecule’’ implies a small molecule that targets core AD pathology (e.g., BACE, tau) — donepezil targets acetylcholinesterase (a neurotransmitter enzyme), not amyloid/tau, so it does not fit that disease‑modifying category; ‘‘Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement’’ would apply if the primary aim were to treat behavioral/psychiatric symptoms specifically (here the trial targets overall effectiveness/safety for AD cognitive stages). Therefore the best fit is ‘‘cognitive enhancer’’, since donepezil is used to improve or stabilize cognition and global function in AD. Relevant sources (mechanism, symptomatic effect, and the trial listing) are cited. citeturn1search1turn1search8turn0search6
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests donepezil hydrochloride (E2020), a centrally acting, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases synaptic acetylcholine to improve cognition — this intervention targets the cholinergic neurotransmitter system rather than amyloid/tau pathology, so it best fits CADRO category D (Neurotransmitter Receptors / neurotransmitter systems). citeturn0search6turn0search3

Act: Extracted details — Drug name: Donepezil hydrochloride (E2020; Aricept). Modality: small‑molecule acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (cholinergic/synaptic enhancer). Indication/use in AD: symptomatic cognitive improvement for mild, moderate and severe AD (not disease‑modifying). Assigned CADRO category: D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn0search3turn0search0turn0search4

Reflect: Confirmation — Donepezil acts by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase (increasing acetylcholine availability) and is used as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer; it does not target core AD pathologies (amyloid or tau) nor is it a biologic or multi-target agent, so D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the most specific CADRO match. If one insisted on a label strictly mentioning "receptor," note donepezil targets the cholinergic system enzymatically (AChE) rather than a receptor protein, but CADRO's Neurotransmitter/Receptor category encompasses cholinergic neurotransmission interventions. citeturn0search6turn0search1

Web search results (sources used): 1) Aricept / Pfizer — FDA approval and statement that Aricept is approved for all stages of AD and is symptomatic (not a cure). citeturn0search0 2) Alzforum — donepezil overview: small molecule, cholinergic system target, reversible AChE inhibitor; widely used symptomatic treatment. citeturn0search1 3) DrugBank — donepezil described as a small‑molecule acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (mechanism). citeturn0search3 4) PMC review (pharmacological treatment of AD) — places donepezil among symptomatic cholinesterase inhibitors and notes it does not modify disease course. citeturn0search4 5) SmPC / pharmacology monograph (Aricept) — specific statement of reversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase and enhancement of cholinergic function. citeturn0search6
